results.title: 11'09''01 - September 11
results.creator_credit: Galatée Films, CIH Shorts, Catherine Dussart Productions (CDP), Comme des Cinémas, Imamura Productions, La Générale de Production, Les Films 13, Les Films de la Plaine, MISR International Films, Makhmalbaf Film House Productions, Sequence 19 Productions, Sixteen Films, Studio Maj, StudioCanal, Zeta Film (MX), Sabrina Dhawan, Danis Tanović, Ken Loach, Nicolas Mauvernay, Paul Laverty, Jacques Perrin, Claude Lelouch, Alejandro González Iñárritu, Vladimir Vega, Sean Penn, Mira Nair, Youssef Chahine, Amos Gitai, Shōhei Imamura, Samira Makhmalbaf, Idrissa Ouedraogo, Pierre Uytterhoeven, Marie-Jose Sanselme and Daisuke Tengan
results.headline_credit: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Burkina Faso, Egypt, France, India, Iran, Israel, Japan, Mexico, United Kingdom and United States of America, 2002
results.brief_description: 11 directors show their view on the terrorist attacks on the world trade center in New York.

constellations_other.name: Post-9/11
constellations_other.description: The attacks on the World Trader Center in New York City on September 11 2001 were viewed on live television by audiences around the world. The effects of the attack have been explored across various forms of media.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Galatée Films, CIH Shorts, Catherine Dussart Productions (CDP), Comme des Cinémas, Imamura Productions, La Générale de Production, Les Films 13, Les Films de la Plaine, MISR International Films, Makhmalbaf Film House Productions, Sequence 19 Productions, Sixteen Films, Studio Maj, StudioCanal, Zeta Film (MX), Sabrina Dhawan, Danis Tanović, Ken Loach, Nicolas Mauvernay, Paul Laverty, Jacques Perrin, Claude Lelouch, Alejandro González Iñárritu, Vladimir Vega, Sean Penn, Mira Nair, Youssef Chahine, Amos Gitai, Shōhei Imamura, Samira Makhmalbaf, Idrissa Ouedraogo, Pierre Uytterhoeven, Marie-Jose Sanselme and Daisuke Tengan

results.title: [CENSORED]
results.creator_credit: Arenamedia, Chloé Brugalé and Sari Braithwaite
results.brief_description: An essay film by filmmaker and archivist Sari Braithwaite, [CENSORED] offers an overview of film censorship in Australia, told through an ever-changing collage of images compiled from the footage that was cut from films released domestically between 1958 and 1971.

constellations_other.name: My Hometown: Archives woven into new narrative
constellations_other.description: Offering viewers a snapshot of life on the road for an Australian touring band in the 1960s, 'My Hometown', directed by Sari Braithwaite was developed reimagining archival 8mm footage shot by drummer Leon Isackson.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

results.description: An essay film by filmmaker and archivist Sari Braithwaite, [CENSORED] offers an overview of film censorship in Australia, told through an ever-changing collage of images compiled from the footage that was cut from films released domestically between 1958 and 1971.
description_for_label: An essay film by filmmaker and archivist Sari Braithwaite, [CENSORED] offers an overview of film censorship in Australia, told through an ever-changing collage of images compiled from the footage that was cut from films released domestically between 1958 and 1971.

results.title: "Shia Labeouf" Live

constellations_other.name: Now watch this
constellations_other.description: In a video-saturated world, how do you keep focus? Do you keep a close eye on one thing, or step back and watch the parade of images go by, to see the whole thing?

results.description: “Shia LaBeouf” is a comedic song by Rob Cantor about actor Shia LaBeouf. The song, which was released in 2012, depicts LaBeouf as an “actual cannibal” who kills other people for sport. - Wikipedia
description_for_label: “Shia LaBeouf” is a comedic song by Rob Cantor about actor Shia LaBeouf. The song, which was released in 2012, depicts LaBeouf as an “actual cannibal” who kills other people for sport. - Wikipedia

images.caption: Still from "Shia LaBeouf" LIVE, directed by Randall Maxwell

results.title: [Dr. Stuart Fraser Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Dr Stuart Fraser (b.1898) was an amateur 16mm filmmaker. He studied medicine in Melbourne, graduating in 1923. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by his son, Graeme Fraser.

This film features children at play in Elwood, Victoria, in the 1930s.

In the film we a see a young toddler playing in a well-maintained suburban garden. The toddler can be seen playing with a variety of garden sprinklers, with and without water, and various toys.

A notable part sees a toddler riding a pony on the Elwood foreshore near Ormond Esplanade. The short glimpse we see of the houses in the background provides a fascinating, if very short, contrast to modern day Elwood.

Originally made using 16mm AGFA film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:56:00 toddler holding a metal cigarette case while watching a spinning sprinkler

00:01:13:00 man holding a toddler while they play with his reading glasses

00:01:58:00 dog jumping up trying to reach a teddy bear held by a child

00:02:09:00 lady holding string attached to a pram while rolling it down a driveway towards the camera

00:02:39:00 baby in yard with teddy bear

00:05:54:00 baby playing with a sprinkler

00:06:18:00 baby in a small tin bath

00:07:45:00 baby eating in highchair

00:08:24:00 baby playing with wooden clothes pegs

00:09:19:00 baby wearing man’s hat in backyard

00:10:03:00 baby playing with blocks, cards, and other toys on a rug in backyard

00:10:37:00 infant being held while wrapped in a blanket

00:11:01:00 toddler in backyard wearing a bag as a hat

00:11:35:00 a lady pushing a pram through botanical gardens, perhaps Royal Melbourne Botanic Gardens

00:12:25:00 baby in pram next to a pond with ducks

00:15:53:00 toddler riding a pony on the Elwood foreshore

00:17:22:00 infant on changing table

00:17:51:00 infant in tin bath

00:18:31:00 young girl playing with toy pram

00:18:59:00 young girl pushing a toy pram containing a teddy bear

results.title: [Dr. Stuart Fraser Home Movies: Tape 1]
results.brief_description:
Dr Stuart Fraser (b. 1898) was an amateur 16mm filmmaker. He studied medicine in Melbourne, graduating in 1923. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by his son, Graeme Fraser.

This film is a compile of various home movies, some under-exposed black and white and some in colour.

The films take place in several locations including suburban backyards and driveways, ski slopes, a farm and various unnamed beaches.

We see children enjoying a family beach holiday, children playing in front of a seawall and one scene shot from above a beach that takes in many beachgoers and a lighthouse.

Film consists of multiple examples of children playing in and around a suburban backyard in the 1930s. The children are seen playing with a variety of toys and riding tricycles and pedal cars, and occasionally tormenting the family dog.

At one point the film takes us to Porepunkah, Victoria. We see competition between seemingly amateur ski jumpers and cross-country skiers on unnamed ski slopes. We also see women standing at a mountain lookout looking across at other mountains.

The film contains scenes on farmland and scenes involving horses being ridden or fed. We see children dressed in school uniform riding horses in a small paddock and people riding horses on a beach track.

We also see a sheep being sheared with manual shears. At one point a boy dressed in full school uniform can be seen shearing the sheep.

Originally made using 16mm AGFA film.

Large sections of this film are under exposed.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:29:00 toddler kneeling in front of sea wall

00:04:04:00 boy pretending to eat a crab at the beach

00:05:37:00 a young girl at the beach wearing a bucket on head walks towards the camera carrying a small football by the laces

00:06:11:00 people walking a beach track towards the camera

00:06:40:00 people riding horses on a beach track

00:07:26:00 young boy holding a toy gun

00:07:50:00 two children digging at the beach

00:07:57:00 people canoeing toward the camera that appears to also be in the water or another boat

00:08:13:00 men in bathing costumes lifting children out of the water with beach huts seen in the background

00:09:17:00 children in driveway playing with toy cars and trains on string

00:09:34:00 three toy trains lined up

00:11:25:00 closeup of a young boy holding a toy bus in front of his face between him and camera

00:12:04:00 children playing on luggage and boxes possibly noting the end of a holiday

00:12:15:00 children on tricycles in backyard

00:12:50:00 children playing a in a disused chicken coop

00:13:43:00 children at a birthday party

00:14:13:00 girl on a seesaw in a suburban park

00:14:47:00 boy sliding down a slide backwards

00:15:45:00 boy playing on a disused canon

00:19:20:00 two children walk toward the camera, it cuts, and we see them walking away from the camera as if they walked through it and toward a house in the distance

00:20:07:00 three young children standing in front of a house

00:20:11:00 two girls in a boat on a river

00:21:48:00 people enjoying an indoor boat ride

00:22:18:00 as people ride the boats a Peter’s ice cream truck can be seen passing in the background

00:22:55:00 people riding a miniature railway

00:23:29:00 dodgem cars with attendants dressed in hats and white coats

00:26:10:00 children riding tricycles and pedal cars in a driveway with the family car parked in the background

00:26:41:00 three children lined up in or on their chosen tricycle or pedal car

00:27:08:00 a young girl teasing the family dog with a variety of toys before the dog snaps at her

00:27:35:00 children riding horses

00:29:57:00 man lights pipe before discarding a match in a paddock

00:30:27:00 two children annoying the family dog

00:31:10:00 persistent young girl sits on family dog

00:31:55:00 Porepunkah sign

00:31:58:00 a panning shot of Victorian alps

00:32:15:00 three women standing on a lookout with Victoria alps in the background

00:32:20:00 cross country skiers slowly ski away from the camera

00:33:17:00 two men skiing downhill on one set of skis

00:33:31:00 people ski jumping off a wooden ramp

00:35:11:00 children at a school sports meeting

00:37:13:00 a young boy and girl sit in hay with a dog in front of a car

00:37:34:00 shot of a lighthouse and seaside and flagpole

00:37:43:00 people at the beach filmed from behind and above

00:38:05:00 lighthouse with waves rolling in in the background

00:39:50:00 young children riding a horse

00:39:52:00 a boy and a girl ride bikes towards the camera in a backyard

00:40:24:00 boy fixing bike in backyard

00:40:39:00 boy playing with a gun in backyard

00:41:00:00 man feeding horses with mountains in the background

00:41:13:00 sheep running through a paddock gate

00:41:19:00 a girl riding a horse through a paddock with mountains seen in the background

00:41:25:00 man shearing a sheep with manual shears

00:41:56:00 a boy shears a sheep in school uniform

00:42:59:00 a girl dressed in school uniform rides a horse toward the camera

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 20]
results.brief_description:
This film is a vignette of family life in the suburbs, including a backyard barbeque and a trip to the Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show. There are good examples of men’s, women’s and children’s fashion of the 1960s. This glimpse of the Royal Melbourne Show is a nostalgic journey back in time.

The title on the film can indicates that it is 1966 and Joy’s party.

We see a backyard gathering with adults and children. It is possibly a birthday party. Maurie drinks beer and poses for the camera. He and Val share a kiss and tend to the barbeque. To the amusement of others, one party goer bursts into a spontaneous dance sequence. In the background we see a Hills Hoist clothes line and what could possibly be an outhouse, or outdoor toilet. Handwritten humorous signs are displayed in various locations around the backyard. One sign reads “To Be Seen Stand Up, To be Heard Speak Up, To be Appreciated, Shut Up”.

There is a trip to the Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show. The film shows signage for Peter’s Ice Cream, Coca-Cola and Four N Twenty Snack Bar. A man on stilts walks in front of the Four N Twenty Snack Bar sign. The children eat toffee apples and explore the sights, including the entrance to the animal pavilion at the show.

The film finishes with images of signs advertising Ross Wylie, Graham Chapman and Mike Furber, who were a part of the popular music scene in Australia at the time. There is also a graphic sign which reads “the Up and Coming of Stage Radio, Stars of Sunshine Records”.

Originally made on 8mm film.
results.title_for_label: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 20]

To the amusement of others, one party goer bursts into a spontaneous dance sequence. In the background we see a Hills Hoist clothes line and what could possibly be an outhouse, or outdoor toilet. Handwritten humorous signs are displayed in various locations around the backyard. One sign reads “To Be Seen Stand Up, To be Heard Speak Up, To be Appreciated, Shut Up”.

There is a trip to the Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show. The film shows signage for Peter’s Ice Cream, Coca-Cola and Four N Twenty Snack Bar. A man on stilts walks in front of the Four N Twenty Snack Bar sign. The children eat toffee apples and explore the sights, including the entrance to the animal pavilion at the show.

The film finishes with images of signs advertising Ross Wylie, Graham Chapman and Mike Furber, who were a part of the popular music scene in Australia at the time. There is also a graphic sign which reads “the Up and Coming of Stage Radio, Stars of Sunshine Records”.

Originally made on 8mm film.
description_for_label:
This film is a vignette of family life in the suburbs, including a backyard barbeque and a trip to the Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show. There are good examples of men’s, women’s and children’s fashion of the 1960s. This glimpse of the Royal Melbourne Show is a nostalgic journey back in time.

The title on the film can indicates that it is 1966 and Joy’s party.

We see a backyard gathering with adults and children. It is possibly a birthday party. Maurie drinks beer and poses for the camera. He and Val share a kiss and tend to the barbeque. To the amusement of others, one party goer bursts into a spontaneous dance sequence. In the background we see a Hills Hoist clothes line and what could possibly be an outhouse, or outdoor toilet. Handwritten humorous signs are displayed in various locations around the backyard. One sign reads “To Be Seen Stand Up, To be Heard Speak Up, To be Appreciated, Shut Up”.

There is a trip to the Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show. The film shows signage for Peter’s Ice Cream, Coca-Cola and Four N Twenty Snack Bar. A man on stilts walks in front of the Four N Twenty Snack Bar sign. The children eat toffee apples and explore the sights, including the entrance to the animal pavilion at the show.

The film finishes with images of signs advertising Ross Wylie, Graham Chapman and Mike Furber, who were a part of the popular music scene in Australia at the time. There is also a graphic sign which reads “the Up and Coming of Stage Radio, Stars of Sunshine Records”.

Originally made on 8mm film.

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
This film shows suburban street scenes, a trip to the country and a visit to an animal shelter. There are good examples of 1960s fashion, suburban architecture and cars reflective of the era.

The film opens with Maurie and friends playfully posing with each other and performing for the camera in a tree-lined suburban street, possibly in Albert Park.

The friends all get into a Morris Major Elite (1962-1964) waving as they drive down the street past a Chrysler AP2 Royal (1958-1961). Single-story terrace houses can be seen in the background.

The family makes a stop-over at a cat and kitten shelter. A handwritten sign scrawled across the side of the building reads: “All cats and kittens in the hostel are stray and unwanted. Their health cannot be guaranteed. Please consult your vet and have your cat immunised immediately”. Beside the writing there is another sign reading “Kindly give a donation thank you”. Val plays with a kitten and presumably adopts it as she carries it into their car.

Families enjoy a couple of trips to the country, including a picnic under pine trees. A small boy attempts to climb one of the trees with hands-on assistance from Maurie. Val swings from a branch, flailing her legs comically. Lunch is cooked on a portable tripod-style wood-fuelled barbeque, while people sit in plastic banana lounges and picnic chairs. There is general banter and typical outdoor revelry among the friends. A large, non-functioning steam train serves as an improvised playground for the children.

Originally made on 8mm film.

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 18]
results.brief_description:
This film is a vignette of family life played out in the suburbs and on holiday in the Narrabeen Lakes, New South Wales. The title on the film reel indicates that some of the footage is filmed around Christmas time and at Narrabeen Lakes.

The film opens with scenes of a primary school playground. Children line up outside for roll call and morning announcements. Teachers organise the formation of groups and lead their charges into the school building.

In a suburban backyard we see a young swashbuckling pyjama-clad pirate, possibly showing off his recent Christmas presents. With a passionfruit vine for an audience, he demonstrates his swordsmanship and fancy footwork around the Hills Hoist clothes line.

Maurie blows up an inflatable wading pool which is filled with water for the children to play in.

The adults imbibe in convivial Christmas drinks, with one of the cohort entering into the spirit of the pirate theme, brandishing a dagger and wearing a pirate hat in a jaunty fashion.

A family road trip takes us across a bridge to what could be the Narrabeen lakes area, Sydney’s Northern Beaches largest estuary system.

On and beside the lake we see some water ski action, water ski hire facilities, and an EJ Holden parked on the side of the road.

A cliff top walk reveals ocean views and an Austin Cambridge car (c. 1965) parked beside a view point.

Originally made on 8mm film.

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 17]
results.brief_description:
This film is a vignette of suburban family life and recreation.

Some sections of this film are underexposed and a hair in the gate appears throughout.

The film opens with scenes of a rugby Union football match which could possibly be an inter-school sports match.

On a suburban street we see a group of teenage boys riding bicycles past parked cars which include a Buick, a Toyota Corolla and a Datsun 180B hitched up to a trailer.

The cyclists accompany the Datsun as it is driven along a Melbourne street past traffic lights, a Clearway sign and a Mobil petrol station.

Inside a weatherboard house, a white cat resides. The human incumbents mug for the camera. Marty (Maurie and Val’s son) pulls faces and tumbles about in slapstick prattfalls. He performs a Fireman carry on a damsel in distress. Playfully, he perches Val Jellay on his lap.

Originally made on 8mm film

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 16]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a family holiday in Cairns and Kuranda in North Queensland.

The film opens with scenes shot from the bow of an Attack Class patrol boat, the HMAS Barbette, which was re-located from Sydney to the port at Cairns in 1971.

As the patrol boat travels on the ocean, we see the vessels’s name plate reading “Barbette” and various equipment on the deck including armament. We see naval vessels sailing behind and flanking the Barbette, and Maurie’s son on board.

The family join a sightseeing tour on board the Kuranda Scenic Railway. As the train climbs through the Macalister Ranges we see the surrounding countryside including farms, ravines, the Barron Falls, the Barron River and the Barron Falls Weir. The film also shows the front carriages of the train snaking their way along the railway track.

Originally made on 8mm film

Selected highlight
00:01:55:00 Carriages of the Kuranda Scenic Railway
